Content.Name: Course Offerings
Content.Title: Family History Research Course Offerings
Content.Abstract: BYU-Idaho has partnered with the Family History Department of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to create online family history courses. These courses will teach students the fundamental skills they need to become capable family history researchers and how to establish a successful research business.
Content.BodyCopy:
BYU-Idaho has partnered with the Family History Department of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to create online family history courses. These courses will teach students the fundamental skills they need to perform competent research or prepare for professional certification as a genealogist.

For information on how to apply or register for these courses, visit our application page.

FHGEN 111 Introduction to Family History Research

Part One: Record Groups and Methodology

Learn basic genealogical research principles using United States records, identify original sources, record genealogical information using professional standards, use key record sources to identify ancestors, and organize family history information.

More Information 

FHGEN112 Introduction to Family History Research

Part Two: Analysis of Research Evidence

Learn to use facts, proofs, evidence, and sources to build a case for accurate genealogical conclusions; analyze and weigh evidence to meet genealogical proof standards; cite sources using professional standards; and place ancestors in historical context.

More Information

FHGEN120 Internet and Computer Skills

Learn genealogical software, key genealogical resources on the Internet, and the computer skills essential for genealogical research.

More Information 

FHGEN 130 Paleography

Learn how to decipher handwriting found in early English, German and Nordic genealogical documents.

More Information | Apply | Register

FHGEN 140 Genealogical Writing

Learn principles of effective report writing for genealogical projects including formatting, documentation, source citations, and presentation of genealogical data.  Learn how to prepare effective genealogical reports for clients.

More Information

FHGEN 160 The Family and Society

Learn the social history of families and how the historical events affected family life and the creation of records in the United States.

More Information 

FHGEN 211 Research Methodology, Part 1

Learn the principles of effective genealogical research methodology.  Students will identify research problems, plan and execute strategy, compile and analyze evidence, assemble documents, cite sources, and produce a professional and well-organized report.

More Information 

FHGEN 212 Research Methodology Part 2

This is a continuation of "Research Methodology Part 1" and provides additional practice in effective research methods. Students will solve genealogical problems and write professional research reports.

More Information 

Geographic Specializations

Learn how to do genealogical research in a specific geographical region. Students seeking the degree will take parts 1 and 2 of the area they choose. Students will learn historical background, key record types for the area, and how to use them to find genealogical information. Students will solve area-specific research problems and produce research reports.

U.S. Specialization
FHGEN 251A Geographic Specialization Course 1: U.S. Regions Research, Part 1
FHGEN 252A Geographic Specialization Course 2: U.S. Regions Research, Part 2

British Isles Specialization
FHGEN 251B Geographic Specialization Course 1: British Isles Regions Research, Part 1
FHGEN 252B Geographic Specialization Course 2: British Isles Regions Research, Part 2

Germany Specialization
FHGEN 251C Geographic Specialization Course 1: Germany Regions Research, Part 1
FHGEN 252C Geographic Specialization Course 2: Germany Regions Research, Part 2

Nordic Specialization
FHGEN 251D Geographic Specialization Course 1: Nordic Regions Research, Part 1
FHGEN 252D Geographic Specialization Course 2: Nordic Regions Research, Part 2

More Information 

FHGEN 270 Genealogy as a Business

Learn how to establish and manage a small genealogical business.  Identify potential job opportunities in the genealogical field.

More Information 

FHGEN 299 Capstone: Professional Research

Apply the analytical and research skills learned throughout the degree program to complete a professional quality research project and client report.

More Information
